Thalidomide is a chemical compound with the molecular formula C13H10N2O4S. It is a synthetic drug that was first introduced in the 1950s as a sedative and later found to have anti-inflammatory and immunomodulatory effects, leading to its use in the treatment of certain medical conditions, including androgen-independent prostate cancer.

Androgen, on the other hand, refers to a class of steroid hormones that play a crucial role in the development and maintenance of male characteristics, such as facial hair, deep voice, and muscle mass. Androgens include testosterone and dihydrotestosterone (DHT), among others. In the context of prostate cancer, androgens can stimulate the growth of cancer cells, and androgen deprivation therapy is sometimes used to slow down the growth of the tumor.
